head.title: Jazz and Blues Improvisation at the Ritz

hedline.hl1: Jazz and Blues Improvisation at the Ritz

block.p: The Jazz and Blues Jam on Saturday night at the Ritz crawled along, the result of bad programming. Though the idea of the show was sound -- to bring together jazz improvisers and blues stars -- the execution was mostly miserable.

The show, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, for example opened with Elvin Bishop, a guitarist and singer who plays decent enough bar band rock-and-roll using blues forms but devoid of blues feeling. The invited guest was the saxophonist Arthur Blythe, one of jazz's most distinct soloists but somebody who plays best in a well-ordered environment; jam sessions aren't his strength. The result was restrained, with Mr. Blythe fighting the rigidity of the 12-bar form, his sound never quite emerging from under the electronic ringing of the band. Bar band blues are obvious and loud and their main power comes from excitement; Mr. Blythe was lost from the first note.

The Jazz and Blues Jam on Saturday night at the Ritz crawled along, the result of bad programming. Though the idea of the show was sound -- to bring together jazz improvisers and blues stars -- the execution was mostly miserable.

The show, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, for example opened with Elvin Bishop, a guitarist and singer who plays decent enough bar band rock-and-roll using blues forms but devoid of blues feeling. The invited guest was the saxophonist Arthur Blythe, one of jazz's most distinct soloists but somebody who plays best in a well-ordered environment; jam sessions aren't his strength. The result was restrained, with Mr. Blythe fighting the rigidity of the 12-bar form, his sound never quite emerging from under the electronic ringing of the band. Bar band blues are obvious and loud and their main power comes from excitement; Mr. Blythe was lost from the first note.

After a miserable set by the organist Jimmy McGriff, who played luke- warm instrumental pop using one hand on the piano and the other on the organ -- and featuring the young jazz musicians Philip and Wynard Harper -- out came the headliner, Bobby (Blue) Bland, to save the long evening from total dissolution.

Mr. Bland was in fine voice and after dispensing with a few early hits -- "I Pity the Fool," "Farther on Up the Road," -- he brought out the saxophonist Lou Donaldson. It was perfect pairing, with Mr. Bland's gracefully agile and blues-laden voice matched with Mr. Donaldson's knowing blues sophistication. Mr. Bland and his band were magnificent on slow blues -- they reached a sort of frozen transparency, with each instrument claiming a personality -- and Mr. Donaldson would step in, swinging blues and be-bop figures in and around the melody. At times Mr. Donaldson placed an outrageously complicated figure in his improvisations; it had both the band and the audience laughing at his audacity.
